thread.title: Kansas officials await figures on tax collection this month
thread.title_full: Kansas officials await figures on tax collection this month

title: Kansas officials await figures on tax collection this month
text:
Kansas officials waiting to learn how tax collections in July compare with state projections 
THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Published: 7/31/15 11:25 am EDT - Updated: 7/31/15 11:29 am EDT 
TOPEKA, Kansas â€” Kansas officials are close to learning whether the state's tax collections this month met expectations. 
The report due Friday from the Department of Revenue is coming a day after Gov. Sam Brownback's budget director announced $63 million in adjustments to the state's $15.4 billion budget to lessen the chances of a deficit. 
The state finished its 2015 fiscal year on June 30 with tax collections $26 million short of expectations at $5.7 billion. The shortfall was about 0.5 percent. 
State officials are watching tax collections closely. Even with the budget adjustments and sales and cigarette tax increases taking effect this month, the state won't have much of a financial cushion in cash reserves. 
Budget problems arose after lawmakers slashed income taxes in 2012 and 2013 as an economic stimulus. 
This story has been corrected to show that the budget adjustments announced Thursday were $63 million, not $50 million.
